paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: The paper investigates whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments receiving both intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls receiving vaccine only, ICI only, or vehicle.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort (total)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Total metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Metastatic patients who had received prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination and were subsequently treated with ICI.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
